block.p: A new guerrilla group attacked police and military posts in nearly simultaneous strikes in four Mexican states, leaving 13 dead and 23 wounded in the bloodiest insurgent violence in nearly three years.

Shops and buses in the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and East Jerusalem came to a halt in response to Yasir Arafat's call for a four-hour protest against the hard-line policies of the new Israeli Government.
Almost two years after Jordan and Israel signed a peace treaty, trade between the two states is a mere trickle, joint ventures are few, and the old stereotypes and suspicions still loom large.
American troops briefly detained some 65 Bosnian Serbs after an assault on Muslim refugees returning to former homes in one of the most serious confrontations since the arrival of NATO forces.
The United States has accused Iran of helping smuggle refined oil products out of Iraq in violation of the United Nations sanctions.
A Russian jetliner carrying 140 people, mostly coal miners and their families, crashed into a mountain on the Norwegian island of Spitsbergen in the Arctic Ocean. There appeared to be no survivors.
Japanese authorities arrested a prominent physician who many of Japan's hemophiliacs say bears responsibility for their infection with the virus that causes AIDS.
Orange Journal: A mayor turns on the public library.
President Clinton accepted his party's nomination for a second term, declaring that ''hope is back in America.'' A1
Dick Morris, the President's chief campaign adviser, gave his resignation after a report that he had a relationship with a call girl. A1
News Analysis: The Morris resignation could not possibly have come at a worse time, just a few hours before Bill Clinton appealed for the support of the convention. A1

CLINTON PUTS DELEGATES AT EASE President Clinton's acceptance speech sent cheering delegates to their feet and was welcome relief after a long day of sensational news about the President's main election strategist. A1
The Morris affair plays into the Dole strategy, aides said. A22
The Kennedys, it seems, have been everywhere in Chicago. A24
The Democrats have been getting more air time. A19
The Federal Aviation Administration said that Valujet Airlines could start flying again. A12

Chants, marches and vigils are now a staple in many neighborhoods where residents use methods taught by Herman Wrice, an anti-drug crusader who believes in fighting drug dealers by confronting them. A12
Residents of Chicago neighborhoods near the Democrats' convention saw many improvements before the meeting. But they are not uniformly behind the party's candidate. A12
Prosecutors asked the judge in the Oklahoma bombing trial to deny the request of Timothy McVeigh to give a series of television and newspaper interviews. A16
Nearly two weeks after winning the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, Ross Perot is still trying to settle on a running mate. A24
Marines are joining the battle against fires in the West. A16

Federal investigators have created a sophisticated computer simulation of the final moments of T.W.A. Flight 800 that has helped them visualize the probable focal point of the explosion that ultimately split the plane. A1
Baseball: Yanks get hammered by Angels B9
Bad blood between Piniella and O'Neill B11
Column: Vecsey on baseball feud B9
Golf: Tiger Woods's pro debut B9
Tennis: Agassi comes back to beat Paes. B9
Mansions, narrow streets and a foghorn in Newport, R.I. C1
The theater world ponders the void left by Bernard B. Jacobs. C3
Music: The Gin Blossoms and Lush. C2
Dance: Two spectacles in a park. C8
Works by Jack B. Keats. C27
Books: Writings by Bruce Chatwin. C27
Robert Reinhold, former reporter for The New York Times
Helen Kushnick, former manager of Jay Leno
A. M. Rosenthal: The Chinese missiles.
Peter Mayle: Peace and quiet in the Hamptons.
Ed Rollins: A boost for the G.O.P.
Susan Estrich: No threat to Clinton.
